column1: Brent Ward Jett, Jr. is a Captain in the United States Navy and a NASA astronaut.
Born October 5, 1958, in Pontiac, Michigan, but considers Fort Lauderdale, Florida, to be his hometown.
Married to Janet Leigh Lyon of Patuxent River, Maryland.
Jett was designated a Naval Aviator in March 1983, and reported to VF-101 at Naval Air Station Oceana, Virginia for initial F-14 Tomcat training.
Upon completion of this training, he was assigned to VF-74 and made overseas deployments to the Mediterranean Sea and Indian Ocean aboard the USS Saratoga.
While assigned to VF-74, he was designated as an airwing qualified Landing Signal Officer (LSO) and also attended the Navy Fighter Weapons School (TOPGUN).
Jett returned to the operational Navy in September 1991 and was again assigned to VF-74, flying the F-14B aboard the USS Saratoga.
He has logged over 4,000 flight hours in more than 30 different aircraft and has over 450 carrier landings.
Selected by NASA in March 1992, Jett reported to the Johnson Space Center in August 1992.
After two years of various technical assignments in the Astronaut Office, Jett was assigned to his first mission as the pilot of STS-72.

column2: A year later he again served as pilot on STS-81.

column1: From June 1997 to February 1998, he served as NASA Director of Operations at the Yuri Gagarin Cosmonaut Training Center, Star City, Russia.

column2: Two years later he was the Commander on STS-97.

column1: Finally, he served as the Commander of Space Shuttle Atlantis on STS-115.
Jett retired from the U.S. Navy in July 2007, but remained with NASA.
In November 2007, he was appointed as Director of Flight Crew Operations, a position he currently holds.
STS-97: Endeavour (November 30 to December 11, 2000) was the fifth American mission to build and enhance the capabilities of the International Space Station.

column2: STS-97 delivered the first set of U.S.-provided solar arrays and batteries as well as radiators to provide cooling.

column1: Three spacewalks were conducted to complete assembly operations while the arrays were attached and unfurled.

column2: A communications system for voice and telemetry was also installed.

column1: STS-115: Atlantis (September 9, 2006 - September 21, 2006) was the first assembly mission to the International Space Station after the Columbia disaster.
STS-115 delivered a new truss segment, including solar panels, to the station.
